history.content:
There are I think only two relevant courses here, EECS151 and CS152. Someone else can chime in on 151 since I haven't taken it(yet) but I don't think that it will be very relevant for work primarily in software.

As far as 152 goes, I don't really think that you will learn too much more about how to optimize software around hardware than you would learn in CS61C. Most of 152 deals with increasing performance in ways that are not visible to the programmer and without affecting correctness. It would be more accurate to say that understanding how software is designed is extremely necessary for designing hardware; the primary ways that hardware affects how you might design your software are well covered in 61C.

I think the above descriptions should give some insight into why very few people take these classes; they're difficult and require different paradigms than writing software, while not being very useful if your interests lie only in software. As a result they are pretty much taken primarily by people with strong interest in these areas.

---

Took 151 last semester. Wouldn't really recommend it if you don't plan on going into hardware design; certainly there are a few neat insights, but nothing that isn't covered in 61C (caches, slowness of memory, hazards, etc.).

There are I think only two relevant courses here, EECS151 and CS152. Someone else can chime in on 151 since I haven't taken it(yet) but I don't think that it will be very relevant for work primarily in software.

As far as 152 goes, I don't really think that you will learn too much more about how to optimize software around hardware than you would learn in CS61C. Most of 152 deals with increasing performance in ways that are not visible to the programmer and without affecting correctness. It would be more accurate to say that understanding how software is designed is extremely necessary for designing hardware; the primary ways that hardware affects how you might design your software are well covered in 61C.

I think the above descriptions should give some insight into why very few people take these classes; they're difficult and require different paradigms than writing software, while not being very useful if your interests lie only in software. As a result they are pretty much taken primarily by people with strong interest in these areas.

for those of you who have taken any of these lower level courses, can you comment on how helpful you thought it was to the average cs major who wants to work mostly in software? does knowing how to design hardware help you work with software? 

it seems like not many cs majors take cs15x courses. why is that?
history.subject: cs15* courses review
